job_title: Front of House in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Good working environment and good management
cons: scheduling is a little off but usually it works out fine

job_title: Head of Professional Services in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros: Annual salary increments, holiday entitlements, flexible hours, campus facilities
cons: There are some great people working at Heriot-Watt University but senior leadership is appalling. Top-heavy, arrogant, complacent, only interested in themselves and with virtually no grasp on how to address the challenges the institution is facing. I raised serious concerns about wellbeing and strategy but my manager basically gaslit me, telling me the problems I was experiencing were my own fault. I worked there for many years and left for another institution without even a goodbye from management, which tells you everything you need to know about them.

review_title: Part time teaching work while working on your PhD is really fun but doesn't pay well

cons: Lab helping/tutoring pay is barely above minimum wage and you are not paid to prep.

pros: The expertise is very good, especially in Quantum Optics.
cons: The buildings are old and leaky and the location of the campus is annoying to get to from the town centre.

pros: Beautifully kept campus, lots of green space. Some really great frontline staff who work hard and support each other despite institutional failings.
cons: Poor work / life balance due to chronic under resourcing. Top-heavy management structure. Little to no opportunity for career progression outside of upper management. Persistently terrible staff-survey results. Poor long term planning and execution of strategy new initiatives. Serious under-valuing of the importance of IT infrastructure and staff training.

review_title: A learning experience you wish you didn’t have…
pros: • Excellent, helpful, highly skilled colleagues • Beautiful campus • Good leave allowance and decent benefits
cons: • No room for growth or development - no focus on training for employees and when a position opens up at a higher level it’s given to an external candidate. • I’ve worked here long enough and not had a raise in pay once. Also not had one proper performance review as managers change every 6 months. • understaffed and overworked - people are constantly resigning , says a lot about how the management treats people and overworks and underpays them. Be ready to work more, be paid less and not even be offered a word of thanks. Check the records to total the massive number of colleagues who have quit or signed off from work due to stress. • No point raising  the issues as they will just listen and do nothing. They are a tick box exercise.

review_title: Management are running the University into the ground
pros: Work colleagues and Work life balance. Benefits
cons: They had a round of Voluntary redundances and a year later went on a middle management hiring spree. Senior Management have little clue in what they are doing and seem to run the place like a country club. Moral is low, staff are starting to leave due to lack of training, career progression and money being low.

review_title: Some people are great to work with, but serious issues with middle and upper management
pros: Some professors and RAs can be great to work with if you are picky. Great annual leave. Beautiful campus.
cons: 1) The majority of professors are too busy with unrelated admin work. Not much time left for the actual research. 70% of the time admin, 15% teaching 15% research. Thus, the quality of the research suffers. 2) Overall, too focused on generating money. Many management decisions are questionable and often lead to low morale within the research team 3) Because of inefficient work environments, too many RAs complain too much. Overall, no positive atmosphere. 4) Career prospects are minimal.

review_title: Unethical doing within the academic staff and the university knows and does not do anything about it
pros: The university has a really good reputation, but its academic staff are ruining it. It promotes equality and high standard education but when I raised the issue of my supervisors being racist and he did not let me submit any papers and the fact that he threatened me to choose between my PhD and between having publications, the university did not do anything and they kept him continue working and promoted him to be the head of research.
cons:
1) The university may look like promoting for equality, but they are NOT. I was shocked about the Discrimination from my supervisor even though he has a multinational students. I informed the university about him, and they did nothing.
2) If you do not do as your supervisor’s say, even though it is “unethical”, then you are going to risk losing your scholarship and failing your PhD. Example of unethical behaviour, adding the name of your second supervisor on the paper even though he has no idea what the research is about. They say that your supervisor has no influence on your examiner, YES they do. It is kind of like a gang but within an academic that it should has a “high standard” of moral. The deal is, they examine each other students and if the supervisor says they are good to pass, then the examiner will let you pass. 
3) If you have an issue with your supervisor and you escalate it to the university, the university still will take the supervisor side even if he is wrong because he is bringing funding to the university. The university will not allow you to submit your thesis unless the supervisor approve even though you already filed a complaint against the supervisor saying that he does not want you to submit your thesis because he is getting money on every month you stay in the university. 
4) The complaint department in the university is understaffed and the reason for that the supervisors are the one who is bringing funding to the university. If the university took a stand against every wrong doing brought against the supervisors by the students then the university might end up bankrupted. So, it is better to have a complaint department run by one person, so when a student file a complaint against the supervisor, then the complaint person will acknowledge receiving the complaint and then throw it in the trash.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Assistant in Edinburgh, Scotland
pros:
I've been a research associate for over a year now and my opinion about HW is quite negative but maybe I was simply very lucky with my previous places. But some of the reviews show that some people seem to enjoy it... In any case your experience will highly depended on your line manager.

Good things:
1. There is a good cycling route to the campus if you live close to the Union Canal.
2. Nice, green campus.
3. Bike bothy, where you can fix your bike or borrow bikes for a few days.
cons:
1. Campus located out of town, so the commute from Edinburgh takes a bit of time.
2. Food offered at the catering outlets is rather bad and pricey. There are not many microwaves around the buildings to heat up your own food.
3. IT support is quite bad, e.g. physics/engineering IT support may keep their door shut for days, so you cannot access them; you need to remind them a few times to sort out  your stuff. Also printers don't work ~50% of the time, which is rather annoying.
4. I know that there a cases of bullying but nothing has been done about it for years (and nothing will be I am afraid).
5. Employers cannot use the medical service on campus (students and PhD students can).

review_title: Good Place to work in Edinburgh
